title: Does the Red Flag Act allow for the confiscation of weapons without the consent of the judge?
text: The party division over arms control in Wisconsin is as blatant as ever. ∙ Disappointed by the lack of republican action on this subject, Jove. He wanted legislators to adopt the so-called "Red Flag" Act - which would allow judges to take weapons from persons considered dangerous - and to extend background verification to sales between private parties. The majority leader of the Senate, Scott Fitzgerald, immediately announced that it was likely that the meeting would be adjourned as soon as it began, and refused even to vote on the proposals. At the same time, the other major republic in the state legislature - Assembly President Robin Voss - is conducting media tours to defend Republican inaction and condemn the Evers proposals. Then you have to get permission from the judge to do so." Is Voss right that the Red Flag laws allow weapons to be confiscated before the judge gets involved? Let's dig. The Red Flag laws provide a mechanism to take weapons from people who show dangerous behavior before they harm themselves or others. The first such law was passed in Connecticut in 1990, but the second law appeared only in Indiana in 2005. Other states have adopted such laws in recent years following mass shootings by persons who have shown previous warning signs. At least 17 states and District of Colombia now have a Code of Red Science, including several laws passed in 2019, according to the Giffords Legal Centre for the Prevention of Armed Violence, an organization for research and advocacy. Each state allows law enforcement to seek the elimination of weapons, 12 states also allow family or household members to do so, and state studies also allow petitions from medical professionals, coworkers or school staff. The judge (or other judicial officer such as the Commissioner of the Court) usually hears the request and then decides whether to issue a preliminary order without holding a hearing or notifying the owner of the weapon. These orders are provisional and last from two to 21 days according to the state, according to a summary of a number prepared by the non-partisan Legislative Council of Wisconsin. The owner of the weapon is then given the opportunity to present his case at a hearing before the judge decides on a final order. This arrangement usually lasts for one year. Tony Evers mentioned on January 12, 2021 in his speech: "We put $330 million in public school aid - the largest in more than a decade." • January 26, 2021, the various states have different burdens of proof that must be met for a judge to make an order, such as finding the individual is a "high risk" or there is "clear and convincing evidence." If an order is issued, some states require the immediate surrender of weapons, while others allow for a short period of time. A search warrant authorizing detention may also be issued in some states. The proposed Evers Law on Wisconsin requires a hearing within 14 days of the preliminary order and makes the final order effective for one year. It states that weapons should be seized if the judge finds "reasonable grounds that the defendant is highly likely" to harm himself or another person. Applications may be made either for an extension of the final order or for its early termination. The State Act already provides for the surrender of weapons as a result of other judicial conclusions, such as mental health obligations and restraining orders, in accordance with the Legislative Council. You may have noticed that the word "judge" appears repeatedly in the above summary. The Wisconsin proposal, contrary to the Vos description, does not permit the confiscation of any weapon without a warrant.
